Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: The 'nature' of the conditional vs conjunction disjunction etc. (last q of lec 5 + suppl lec)
Input.posts:
I know this is vital so I'd really like to get some confidence on it, and I currently have none! For me it seems that the conditional is fundamentally different to the other logical operators... (For all L)[(Exists S1)Valid(L,S1) implies (For all S2)Valid(L,S2)] And the explanation: For any licence L, if L is valid in some state, then L is valid in every state. I 'get' the reasoning but I only get it because of my knowledge of what is meant (real implication), not because I understand how the logic works. Let's say, for example, that our given licence L it is NOT valid in some state (disqualified for example), so F. I read the above as meaning that it is not valid and yet it is still valid in every state (or possibly every other state), because the antecedent being false means that the entire statement MUST be true. Either that or simply that the conditional really only has meaning if the antecedent is true, and has no real applicability/utility if it is false. And if this is the case then it seems that it is a different beast to conjunction and disjunction. Anyway, I'm still confused!
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
It doesn't sound to me like you're all that confused. ;)
Instructor's post : It doesn't sound to me like you're all that confused. ;)
Upvotes:
0

Input.threadtitle: 'Indirect' proof?
Input.posts:
In Lecture 5, Prof. Devlin referred to his proof that $$\exists x[ x^3+3x+1=0]$$ as an 'indirect proof.' It was my understanding that an 'indirect proof' was a proof by contradiction (and a quick internet search seems to indicate that I'm not the only one with that understanding). The proof presented in the lecture did not seem to fit that format. Is there another definition of 'indirect proof' that I'm not aware of? Thanks.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The other names I know of for the type of proof in the video are 'existence proof' and 'non-constructive proof'.
Instructor's post : The other names I know of for the type of proof in the video are 'existence proof' and 'non-constructive proof'.
Upvotes:
0

Input.threadtitle: Subtle Notation Switch Why?
Input.posts:
In the lecture KD switched notations slightly, but without offering an explanation. When talking about the existential quantifier he used square brackets to enclose the proposition and when talking about the universal quantifier he enclosed the proposition in parenthesis. Did I miss something? Is either notation acceptable? Also, when writing the statement about the square root of two being rational, wouldn't it have been more precise to say: $$(\exists p \in \mathbb{N} ) \wedge (\exists q \in \mathbb{N}) [\sqrt2 = \frac {p} {q} ]$$ or is the $$\wedge$$ assumed?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I talk about this is a number of places -- for example in the video about how to read mathematical formulas.
Instructor's post : I talk about this is a number of places -- for example in the video about how to read mathematical formulas.
Upvotes:
0

Input.threadtitle: The equivalence between P only if Q and if P then Q
Input.posts:
I have tried to figure out the equivalence of those two statements and my inituition and reasoning always through away from right direction, sometimes in my mind i reach aha moment for some seconds and when feel that I still do not understand the concept. Can you please explain how those statements are similiar with each other: P only if Q and if P then Q For me P only if Q should be substituted with if Q then P and it seems to me that the real antecedent of the first statement is Q and P. I know that this is the wrong answer but can not figure out why i understand it wrong. Please help to figure it out.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Focus on the 'only'. The 'if' is leading you astray. Compare P if Q P only if Q
Instructor's post : Focus on the 'only'. The 'if' is leading you astray. Compare P if Q P only if Q

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: The equivalence between P only if Q and if P then Q
Input.posts:
I have tried to figure out the equivalence of those two statements and my inituition and reasoning always through away from right direction, sometimes in my mind i reach aha moment for some seconds and when feel that I still do not understand the concept. Can you please explain how those statements are similiar with each other: P only if Q and if P then Q For me P only if Q should be substituted with if Q then P and it seems to me that the real antecedent of the first statement is Q and P. I know that this is the wrong answer but can not figure out why i understand it wrong. Please help to figure it out.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Focus on the 'only'. The 'if' is leading you astray. Compare P if Q P only if Q
Instructor's post : Focus on the 'only'. The 'if' is leading you astray. Compare P if Q P only if Q

Input.threadtitle: Phi conditional psy equivalence clarification..
Input.posts:
Hello. Would you please give me a hand understanding this: I do not understand, why is this (expression which stands between the 'For example' and 'is equivalent') taken as the example. Is this just for illustrating the conception, or the expression mentioned above has some significant meaning needed to understand the 'phi conditional psy' expression?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Vasiliy - the purpose is to show expressions that are equivalent to one another. Because conditional statements such as $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ are so central to proofs, it's worth knowing their equivalences. Remember, if you have a proof or argument that contains one such equivalent statements, you can substitute into the proof the equivalent conditional statement. In the example given, the two statements are equivalent, which can be shown (1) with a truth table (yielding an equivalent array of truth values for the two expressions) or (2) you can work through each expression until you arrive at the same expression. Taking the expression ($$\phi \wedge \psi$$) $$\vee$$ $$ eg\phi$$ and distributing $$ eg\phi$$ we get the expression ($$ eg\phi$$ $$\vee$$ $$\phi$$) $$\wedge$$ ($$ eg\phi \vee$$ $$\psi$$). Notice that ($$ eg\phi$$ $$\vee$$ $$\phi$$) is a tautology and always true. This leaves you with the truth value being determined by ($$ eg\phi$$ $$\vee$$ $$\phi$$), which is the same as the conditional statement, $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, on the RHS at the start.

Input.threadtitle: necessary/only if - What does it mean?
Input.posts:
$$\psi$$ is necessary for $$\phi$$ I am having trouble with the explanation that '$$\psi$$ will have to hold before there can even be any question of $$\phi$$ holding '. Since the above is supposed to mean the same as '$$\phi$$ implies $$\psi$$' it should have the same truth table.There is a line with $$\phi$$ true and $$\psi$$ false. Sure, the conditional is false in that case, but $$\phi$$ can be true in a situation where $$\psi$$ is false. Should I rather think of it as '$$\psi$$ will have to hold before there can even be any question of $$\phi$$ holding with the added requirement that the conditional has to be true '?
Upvotes:
0
when Phi is ture and Psi is false, “Phi implies Psi” is false. that means Phi does not imply Psi, Phi is not the antecedet of Psi.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Yes, Georg, the validity of the conditional is implicit in these statements.
Instructor's post : Yes, Georg, the validity of the conditional is implicit in these statements.

0

Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: necessary/only if - What does it mean?
Input.posts:
$$\psi$$ is necessary for $$\phi$$ I am having trouble with the explanation that '$$\psi$$ will have to hold before there can even be any question of $$\phi$$ holding '. Since the above is supposed to mean the same as '$$\phi$$ implies $$\psi$$' it should have the same truth table.There is a line with $$\phi$$ true and $$\psi$$ false. Sure, the conditional is false in that case, but $$\phi$$ can be true in a situation where $$\psi$$ is false. Should I rather think of it as '$$\psi$$ will have to hold before there can even be any question of $$\phi$$ holding with the added requirement that the conditional has to be true '?
Upvotes:
0
when Phi is ture and Psi is false, “Phi implies Psi” is false. that means Phi does not imply Psi, Phi is not the antecedet of Psi.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Yes, Georg, the validity of the conditional is implicit in these statements.
Instructor's post : Yes, Georg, the validity of the conditional is implicit in these statements.
Upvotes:
0

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: to KD : I think your Lecture 3 on implication is plainly wrong !
Input.posts:
I had a lot of trouble understanding this lecture... I've spent days on it, trying to figure out why I had this strange feeling about it, why I couldn't integrate blindly these notions, why I couldn't move on to the next lecture, why I kept coming back to this one. I finally came to the conclusion that this lecture is plainly wrong, I think that I've found a lot of errors in it. Here is why : ===================== Definition of implication ===================== 'A implies B' I think the implication definition 'The truth of B follows from the truth of A' you gave in Lecture 3 is ambiguous. Upon the wanted meaning, there is a language ambiguity that carries an additional unwanted meaning : ' For B to be true, A has to be true in the first place' (or 'we can't have B true, if A is not true in the first place' ), which gives an erroneous information about the material conditional truth table case 'False ⇒ True' which (to be consistent with this undesirable meaning) would be 'False' instead of the correct 'True'. I'd rather use a reversed rewording of your definition : 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' , or even simplier : 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' . Both of these definitions are intuitive and doesn't carry the extra undesirable meaning that goes with the definition you provided. ==================================== Filling the material conditional truth table ==================================== As written earlier, 'A implies B' can be defined as 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' or as 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' , which leads to the following material conditional truth table : A B A ⇒ B ---------------------- T T T T F F F T ? (we have no intuition here) F F ? (we have no intuition here) First of all, I will expose the two methods I use to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table, then I'll explain why I disagree with the method you provided in Lecture 3. Method 1 : Rewording the implication definition Saying 'If A is true, then B is necessarly true' is equivalent to saying 'We can't have A true and B false'. This rephrasing can easily be expressed in logical operators as :'¬(A ∧ ¬B)', and the fact that the behaviours of these logical operators are well-known allows us to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table. A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ----------------------------- T T T T F F F T T F F T Method 2 : Identifying and eliminating the unsuitable truth table cases Let's write all of the possible combinations for the unintuitive cases. A B (1) (2) (3) (4) -------------------------------------------------- T T T T T T T F F F F F F T F T F T F F F F T T It's easily understandable that the implication has these two properties : implication is not trivial, implication is asymmetric. (1) This combination is the truth table of the conjonction '∧', and implication is not a conjonction, thus we can eliminate this column. We can also say that this combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. (2) This combination has the same truth table as 'B'. An implication is not trivial, it shouldn't be equivalent to its consequent, thus we can eliminate this column. (3) This combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. It's actually the truth table of the equivalence '⇔', but we can't use this fact here since the equivalence is defined upon the notion of implication wich we're still trying to complete at this moment. (4) By using this elimination process, and after checking that this combination is neither trivial nor asymmetric, and that it doesn't match the truth table of another already-known logical operator, we can finally conclude that this column is the only one suitable for the material conditional. ====================================================== The distinction between 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' ====================================================== During Lecture 3 (21:30 on the video timeline), you provide a method to fill the material conditional by using the definition of 'A doesn't imply B'. I think you're mistaken. Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration : Your exact words are : 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', and you claim that for all the other cases, we'll get 'False'. You've come to the 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement by refering to the 'True ⇒ False' case of the material conditional (which we know gives 'False', and become 'True' for the 'non-implication'), but you can't know at this stage that it's the only case of the material conditional that leads to 'False', therefore you can't know whether or not it's the only case that leads to 'True' for the 'non-implication'. And yet, you go on with your demonstration as if it was the case : you're using this 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement, which we don't know whether or not it captures the complete behaviour of 'not-implication', to fill the totality of the 'not-implication' truth table. My understanding is that we can't fill the totality of a truth table only by using a statement who doesn't encompass all the behaviours of the logical operator we're assessing. Actually it turns out that your statement encompass all the behaviours of 'not-implication', but at this stage of the demonstration we couldn't know it : you actually jumped to the conclusion without providing the valid demonstration to back it up. We can't use this method to fill our material conditional truth table. We had no intution for the implication and we have no intuition for the 'non-implication' neither. 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : And there is an even bigger, insidious, and mindboggling issue, which caused me to think a lot before I was able to spot it and formulate it. To fill the incomplete material conditional truth table, your intention was to use the definition of 'does not imply', you said so at two differents moments on the video : [21:30 on timeline] 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', [26:45 on timeline] 'The definition for a False antecedent is based on a truth value analysis of the notion 'does not imply''. But instead of using a 'doesn't imply' definition, you used a 'non-implication' demonstration, which has proved to be erroneous (hence my precedent title : Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration). I think that 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' doesn't express the meaning of 'A doesn't imply B' because it enforces a relationship between A and not-B (A has to be True and B has to be False) instead of expressing an absence of relationship. To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.
Upvotes:
2
Largely agree Professor Devlin could've been more precise in his wording. Instead of 'does not imply' he could have said 'can not imply' or 'definitely does not imply' (which makes 'can not imply' useful for disproving implication). I agree that 'doesn't imply' only definitely implies no causal or logical relation between the contents of the variables. However, couldn't knowing that there's no causal relation (or none better than chance, relative to environmental randomness) be useful in modeling science and probability? Isolating independent variables is extremely important, even if we can't prove that one 'can not imply' the other (which would be better and stronger but not necessarily available). But wouldn't a true 'doesn't imply', 'there is no causal relation between', allow the variables to have *any* truth values with 'doesn't imply' still being true (or false, for that matter, or simply undefined, since it refers to relations beyond pure syntax)? Your first demonstration of how to get the conditional's truth table works well, but there's an issue with your second one: Why can't the last two rows be left undefined? One answer is that if we knew A⇒B is true and the last two rows were undefined or false we could deduce that A must be true. Similar problems arise if we let one be false and the other undefined (if the third row's undefined and the last row's false then A⇒B being false and B being false would allow us to deduce that A is false, which it clearly shouldn't; and vice versa).

0
it seems helpful to read this post by Fud0 (community TA)
Upvotes:
0
Some work in week 4 took me back to the stuff on “does not imply.” It had to do with the equality of [phi does not imply psi] to [phi AND not-psi]. The statement we are given (because we should somehow relate to it) is: “Phi does not imply psi if: even though phi is T, psi is nevertheless F.” This is not my natural (intuitive) understanding of “does not imply.” In normal usage, although phi “does not imply” psi, it does not preclude psi either--the usage is not exclusive. So thinking through this for hours, my intuitive grasp here relates to negation. I have a better sense of the cases when the antecedent is false leading to implication being true, than to “this does not imply that,” apparently. Thus building the full 'implies' truth table and then forming the negation of its conclusion yields the full “does not imply” truth table. I liked Hadrien’s Method 1: Rewording the implication truth table, but it left me hanging when I really dug into it. Yet KD is a mathematician, so perhaps I’m still not getting this “most difficult part of the entire course.”

Ouch. Most mathematicians believed that Euclid's parallel postulate followed from the others before someone realized that alternate geometries existed and launched an entirely new branch of mathematics. Just because 99.9%% of mathematicians believe something to be true isn't enough for you to challenge their ideas.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
This is a strange thread that seems to be totally off course. As I emphasized at the time, the material conditional is not a definition of implication. As I said, impaction is way too complicated to define within mathematics. Rather, the material conditional is a model for implication that exhibits some features of implication. So there is no question of whether it is 'right' or 'wrong'. Rather the issue is whether the conditional is appropriate or not to use in a given situation. I gave as an example where a professional community agrees that it is appropriate is in the design of computer reasoning systems, where you cannot have an undefined output. More generally, the consensus among mathematicians is that it is a pretty good model for many purposes within mathematics. In the lecture, I provided the rationale that lies behind the particular definition of the conditional. Again, that is not a proof, it is an analysis of implication from the perspective of truth values that leads to a particular definition being adopted. Though K-12 schools seem to leave people thinking that mathematics is all about right or wrong, that's actually not the case. Most mathematicians spend much of their time focusing on how to model real world phenomena. The metric there is not right or wrong -- that has no meaning -- rather on how appropriate is the model. Right or wrong questions apply only when you are working within a particular model, be that model arithmetic, planar Euclidean geometry, Riemannian geometry, general topology, or whatever. Mathematics courses usually focus on working within mathematics, so modeling issues rarely arise. But this is not a mathematics course, it is about mathematical thinking . This is also reflected in the fact that logical correctness is only one of several factors we take into account when evaluating mathematical arguments. For instance, those parameters of opening and closing are significant because they are the mathematical side of the input and output links to the context within which mathematics itself gets applied. (So they are part of the API, in computer programming terminology.) I hope this helps. One of the reason courses like this are called 'transition courses' is that they help high school graduates go beyond the rather narrow view of mathematics that the K-12 system seems to encourage.

A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.
Upvotes:
2
Largely agree Professor Devlin could've been more precise in his wording. Instead of 'does not imply' he could have said 'can not imply' or 'definitely does not imply' (which makes 'can not imply' useful for disproving implication). I agree that 'doesn't imply' only definitely implies no causal or logical relation between the contents of the variables. However, couldn't knowing that there's no causal relation (or none better than chance, relative to environmental randomness) be useful in modeling science and probability? Isolating independent variables is extremely important, even if we can't prove that one 'can not imply' the other (which would be better and stronger but not necessarily available). But wouldn't a true 'doesn't imply', 'there is no causal relation between', allow the variables to have *any* truth values with 'doesn't imply' still being true (or false, for that matter, or simply undefined, since it refers to relations beyond pure syntax)? Your first demonstration of how to get the conditional's truth table works well, but there's an issue with your second one: Why can't the last two rows be left undefined? One answer is that if we knew A⇒B is true and the last two rows were undefined or false we could deduce that A must be true. Similar problems arise if we let one be false and the other undefined (if the third row's undefined and the last row's false then A⇒B being false and B being false would allow us to deduce that A is false, which it clearly shouldn't; and vice versa).

Some work in week 4 took me back to the stuff on “does not imply.” It had to do with the equality of [phi does not imply psi] to [phi AND not-psi]. The statement we are given (because we should somehow relate to it) is: “Phi does not imply psi if: even though phi is T, psi is nevertheless F.” This is not my natural (intuitive) understanding of “does not imply.” In normal usage, although phi “does not imply” psi, it does not preclude psi either--the usage is not exclusive. So thinking through this for hours, my intuitive grasp here relates to negation. I have a better sense of the cases when the antecedent is false leading to implication being true, than to “this does not imply that,” apparently. Thus building the full 'implies' truth table and then forming the negation of its conclusion yields the full “does not imply” truth table. I liked Hadrien’s Method 1: Rewording the implication truth table, but it left me hanging when I really dug into it. Yet KD is a mathematician, so perhaps I’m still not getting this “most difficult part of the entire course.”

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
This is a strange thread that seems to be totally off course. As I emphasized at the time, the material conditional is not a definition of implication. As I said, impaction is way too complicated to define within mathematics. Rather, the material conditional is a model for implication that exhibits some features of implication. So there is no question of whether it is 'right' or 'wrong'. Rather the issue is whether the conditional is appropriate or not to use in a given situation. I gave as an example where a professional community agrees that it is appropriate is in the design of computer reasoning systems, where you cannot have an undefined output. More generally, the consensus among mathematicians is that it is a pretty good model for many purposes within mathematics. In the lecture, I provided the rationale that lies behind the particular definition of the conditional. Again, that is not a proof, it is an analysis of implication from the perspective of truth values that leads to a particular definition being adopted. Though K-12 schools seem to leave people thinking that mathematics is all about right or wrong, that's actually not the case. Most mathematicians spend much of their time focusing on how to model real world phenomena. The metric there is not right or wrong -- that has no meaning -- rather on how appropriate is the model. Right or wrong questions apply only when you are working within a particular model, be that model arithmetic, planar Euclidean geometry, Riemannian geometry, general topology, or whatever. Mathematics courses usually focus on working within mathematics, so modeling issues rarely arise. But this is not a mathematics course, it is about mathematical thinking . This is also reflected in the fact that logical correctness is only one of several factors we take into account when evaluating mathematical arguments. For instance, those parameters of opening and closing are significant because they are the mathematical side of the input and output links to the context within which mathematics itself gets applied. (So they are part of the API, in computer programming terminology.) I hope this helps. One of the reason courses like this are called 'transition courses' is that they help high school graduates go beyond the rather narrow view of mathematics that the K-12 system seems to encourage.

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
RequesterFeedback: Hey all, if the instructor is replying to people collectively, please only mark the first relevant post as in the instructions
Input.threadtitle: to KD : I think your Lecture 3 on implication is plainly wrong !
Input.posts:
I had a lot of trouble understanding this lecture... I've spent days on it, trying to figure out why I had this strange feeling about it, why I couldn't integrate blindly these notions, why I couldn't move on to the next lecture, why I kept coming back to this one. I finally came to the conclusion that this lecture is plainly wrong, I think that I've found a lot of errors in it. Here is why : ===================== Definition of implication ===================== 'A implies B' I think the implication definition 'The truth of B follows from the truth of A' you gave in Lecture 3 is ambiguous. Upon the wanted meaning, there is a language ambiguity that carries an additional unwanted meaning : ' For B to be true, A has to be true in the first place' (or 'we can't have B true, if A is not true in the first place' ), which gives an erroneous information about the material conditional truth table case 'False ⇒ True' which (to be consistent with this undesirable meaning) would be 'False' instead of the correct 'True'. I'd rather use a reversed rewording of your definition : 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' , or even simplier : 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' . Both of these definitions are intuitive and doesn't carry the extra undesirable meaning that goes with the definition you provided. ==================================== Filling the material conditional truth table ==================================== As written earlier, 'A implies B' can be defined as 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' or as 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' , which leads to the following material conditional truth table : A B A ⇒ B ---------------------- T T T T F F F T ? (we have no intuition here) F F ? (we have no intuition here) First of all, I will expose the two methods I use to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table, then I'll explain why I disagree with the method you provided in Lecture 3. Method 1 : Rewording the implication definition Saying 'If A is true, then B is necessarly true' is equivalent to saying 'We can't have A true and B false'. This rephrasing can easily be expressed in logical operators as :'¬(A ∧ ¬B)', and the fact that the behaviours of these logical operators are well-known allows us to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table. A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ----------------------------- T T T T F F F T T F F T Method 2 : Identifying and eliminating the unsuitable truth table cases Let's write all of the possible combinations for the unintuitive cases. A B (1) (2) (3) (4) -------------------------------------------------- T T T T T T T F F F F F F T F T F T F F F F T T It's easily understandable that the implication has these two properties : implication is not trivial, implication is asymmetric. (1) This combination is the truth table of the conjonction '∧', and implication is not a conjonction, thus we can eliminate this column. We can also say that this combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. (2) This combination has the same truth table as 'B'. An implication is not trivial, it shouldn't be equivalent to its consequent, thus we can eliminate this column. (3) This combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. It's actually the truth table of the equivalence '⇔', but we can't use this fact here since the equivalence is defined upon the notion of implication wich we're still trying to complete at this moment. (4) By using this elimination process, and after checking that this combination is neither trivial nor asymmetric, and that it doesn't match the truth table of another already-known logical operator, we can finally conclude that this column is the only one suitable for the material conditional. ====================================================== The distinction between 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' ====================================================== During Lecture 3 (21:30 on the video timeline), you provide a method to fill the material conditional by using the definition of 'A doesn't imply B'. I think you're mistaken. Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration : Your exact words are : 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', and you claim that for all the other cases, we'll get 'False'. You've come to the 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement by refering to the 'True ⇒ False' case of the material conditional (which we know gives 'False', and become 'True' for the 'non-implication'), but you can't know at this stage that it's the only case of the material conditional that leads to 'False', therefore you can't know whether or not it's the only case that leads to 'True' for the 'non-implication'. And yet, you go on with your demonstration as if it was the case : you're using this 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement, which we don't know whether or not it captures the complete behaviour of 'not-implication', to fill the totality of the 'not-implication' truth table. My understanding is that we can't fill the totality of a truth table only by using a statement who doesn't encompass all the behaviours of the logical operator we're assessing. Actually it turns out that your statement encompass all the behaviours of 'not-implication', but at this stage of the demonstration we couldn't know it : you actually jumped to the conclusion without providing the valid demonstration to back it up. We can't use this method to fill our material conditional truth table. We had no intution for the implication and we have no intuition for the 'non-implication' neither. 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : And there is an even bigger, insidious, and mindboggling issue, which caused me to think a lot before I was able to spot it and formulate it. To fill the incomplete material conditional truth table, your intention was to use the definition of 'does not imply', you said so at two differents moments on the video : [21:30 on timeline] 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', [26:45 on timeline] 'The definition for a False antecedent is based on a truth value analysis of the notion 'does not imply''. But instead of using a 'doesn't imply' definition, you used a 'non-implication' demonstration, which has proved to be erroneous (hence my precedent title : Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration). I think that 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' doesn't express the meaning of 'A doesn't imply B' because it enforces a relationship between A and not-B (A has to be True and B has to be False) instead of expressing an absence of relationship. To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.

I agree that 'doesn't imply' only definitely implies no causal or logical relation between the contents of the variables. To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.
Upvotes:
2
Largely agree Professor Devlin could've been more precise in his wording. Instead of 'does not imply' he could have said 'can not imply' or 'definitely does not imply' (which makes 'can not imply' useful for disproving implication). I agree that 'doesn't imply' only definitely implies no causal or logical relation between the contents of the variables. However, couldn't knowing that there's no causal relation (or none better than chance, relative to environmental randomness) be useful in modeling science and probability? Isolating independent variables is extremely important, even if we can't prove that one 'can not imply' the other (which would be better and stronger but not necessarily available). But wouldn't a true 'doesn't imply', 'there is no causal relation between', allow the variables to have *any* truth values with 'doesn't imply' still being true (or false, for that matter, or simply undefined, since it refers to relations beyond pure syntax)? Your first demonstration of how to get the conditional's truth table works well, but there's an issue with your second one: Why can't the last two rows be left undefined? One answer is that if we knew A⇒B is true and the last two rows were undefined or false we could deduce that A must be true. Similar problems arise if we let one be false and the other undefined (if the third row's undefined and the last row's false then A⇒B being false and B being false would allow us to deduce that A is false, which it clearly shouldn't; and vice versa).

The statement we are given (because we should somehow relate to it) is: “Phi does not imply psi if: even though phi is T, psi is nevertheless F.” This is not my natural (intuitive) understanding of “does not imply.” In normal usage, although phi “does not imply” psi, it does not preclude psi either--the usage is not exclusive. So thinking through this for hours, my intuitive grasp here relates to negation. I have a better sense of the cases when the antecedent is false leading to implication being true, than to “this does not imply that,” apparently. Thus building the full 'implies' truth table and then forming the negation of its conclusion yields the full “does not imply” truth table. I liked Hadrien’s Method 1: Rewording the implication truth table, but it left me hanging when I really dug into it. Yet KD is a mathematician, so perhaps I’m still not getting this “most difficult part of the entire course.”

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
This is a strange thread that seems to be totally off course. As I emphasized at the time, the material conditional is not a definition of implication. As I said, impaction is way too complicated to define within mathematics. Rather, the material conditional is a model for implication that exhibits some features of implication. So there is no question of whether it is 'right' or 'wrong'. Rather the issue is whether the conditional is appropriate or not to use in a given situation. I gave as an example where a professional community agrees that it is appropriate is in the design of computer reasoning systems, where you cannot have an undefined output. More generally, the consensus among mathematicians is that it is a pretty good model for many purposes within mathematics. In the lecture, I provided the rationale that lies behind the particular definition of the conditional. Again, that is not a proof, it is an analysis of implication from the perspective of truth values that leads to a particular definition being adopted. Though K-12 schools seem to leave people thinking that mathematics is all about right or wrong, that's actually not the case. Most mathematicians spend much of their time focusing on how to model real world phenomena. The metric there is not right or wrong -- that has no meaning -- rather on how appropriate is the model. Right or wrong questions apply only when you are working within a particular model, be that model arithmetic, planar Euclidean geometry, Riemannian geometry, general topology, or whatever. Mathematics courses usually focus on working within mathematics, so modeling issues rarely arise. But this is not a mathematics course, it is about mathematical thinking . This is also reflected in the fact that logical correctness is only one of several factors we take into account when evaluating mathematical arguments. For instance, those parameters of opening and closing are significant because they are the mathematical side of the input and output links to the context within which mathematics itself gets applied. (So they are part of the API, in computer programming terminology.) I hope this helps. One of the reason courses like this are called 'transition courses' is that they help high school graduates go beyond the rather narrow view of mathematics that the K-12 system seems to encourage.

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: to KD : I think your Lecture 3 on implication is plainly wrong !
Input.posts:
I had a lot of trouble understanding this lecture... I've spent days on it, trying to figure out why I had this strange feeling about it, why I couldn't integrate blindly these notions, why I couldn't move on to the next lecture, why I kept coming back to this one. I finally came to the conclusion that this lecture is plainly wrong, I think that I've found a lot of errors in it. Here is why : ===================== Definition of implication ===================== 'A implies B' I think the implication definition 'The truth of B follows from the truth of A' you gave in Lecture 3 is ambiguous. Upon the wanted meaning, there is a language ambiguity that carries an additional unwanted meaning : ' For B to be true, A has to be true in the first place' (or 'we can't have B true, if A is not true in the first place' ), which gives an erroneous information about the material conditional truth table case 'False ⇒ True' which (to be consistent with this undesirable meaning) would be 'False' instead of the correct 'True'. I'd rather use a reversed rewording of your definition : 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' , or even simplier : 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' . Both of these definitions are intuitive and doesn't carry the extra undesirable meaning that goes with the definition you provided. ==================================== Filling the material conditional truth table ==================================== As written earlier, 'A implies B' can be defined as 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' or as 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' , which leads to the following material conditional truth table : A B A ⇒ B ---------------------- T T T T F F F T ? (we have no intuition here) F F ? (we have no intuition here) First of all, I will expose the two methods I use to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table, then I'll explain why I disagree with the method you provided in Lecture 3. Method 1 : Rewording the implication definition Saying 'If A is true, then B is necessarly true' is equivalent to saying 'We can't have A true and B false'. This rephrasing can easily be expressed in logical operators as :'¬(A ∧ ¬B)', and the fact that the behaviours of these logical operators are well-known allows us to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table. A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ----------------------------- T T T T F F F T T F F T Method 2 : Identifying and eliminating the unsuitable truth table cases Let's write all of the possible combinations for the unintuitive cases. A B (1) (2) (3) (4) -------------------------------------------------- T T T T T T T F F F F F F T F T F T F F F F T T It's easily understandable that the implication has these two properties : implication is not trivial, implication is asymmetric. (1) This combination is the truth table of the conjonction '∧', and implication is not a conjonction, thus we can eliminate this column. We can also say that this combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. (2) This combination has the same truth table as 'B'. An implication is not trivial, it shouldn't be equivalent to its consequent, thus we can eliminate this column. (3) This combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. It's actually the truth table of the equivalence '⇔', but we can't use this fact here since the equivalence is defined upon the notion of implication wich we're still trying to complete at this moment. (4) By using this elimination process, and after checking that this combination is neither trivial nor asymmetric, and that it doesn't match the truth table of another already-known logical operator, we can finally conclude that this column is the only one suitable for the material conditional. ====================================================== The distinction between 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' ====================================================== During Lecture 3 (21:30 on the video timeline), you provide a method to fill the material conditional by using the definition of 'A doesn't imply B'. I think you're mistaken. Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration : Your exact words are : 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', and you claim that for all the other cases, we'll get 'False'. You've come to the 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement by refering to the 'True ⇒ False' case of the material conditional (which we know gives 'False', and become 'True' for the 'non-implication'), but you can't know at this stage that it's the only case of the material conditional that leads to 'False', therefore you can't know whether or not it's the only case that leads to 'True' for the 'non-implication'. And yet, you go on with your demonstration as if it was the case : you're using this 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement, which we don't know whether or not it captures the complete behaviour of 'not-implication', to fill the totality of the 'not-implication' truth table. My understanding is that we can't fill the totality of a truth table only by using a statement who doesn't encompass all the behaviours of the logical operator we're assessing. Actually it turns out that your statement encompass all the behaviours of 'not-implication', but at this stage of the demonstration we couldn't know it : you actually jumped to the conclusion without providing the valid demonstration to back it up. We can't use this method to fill our material conditional truth table. We had no intution for the implication and we have no intuition for the 'non-implication' neither. 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : And there is an even bigger, insidious, and mindboggling issue, which caused me to think a lot before I was able to spot it and formulate it. To fill the incomplete material conditional truth table, your intention was to use the definition of 'does not imply', you said so at two differents moments on the video : [21:30 on timeline] 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', [26:45 on timeline] 'The definition for a False antecedent is based on a truth value analysis of the notion 'does not imply''. But instead of using a 'doesn't imply' definition, you used a 'non-implication' demonstration, which has proved to be erroneous (hence my precedent title : Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration). I think that 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' doesn't express the meaning of 'A doesn't imply B' because it enforces a relationship between A and not-B (A has to be True and B has to be False) instead of expressing an absence of relationship. To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.

To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.
Upvotes:
2
Largely agree Professor Devlin could've been more precise in his wording. Instead of 'does not imply' he could have said 'can not imply' or 'definitely does not imply' (which makes 'can not imply' useful for disproving implication). I agree that 'doesn't imply' only definitely implies no causal or logical relation between the contents of the variables. However, couldn't knowing that there's no causal relation (or none better than chance, relative to environmental randomness) be useful in modeling science and probability? Isolating independent variables is extremely important, even if we can't prove that one 'can not imply' the other (which would be better and stronger but not necessarily available). But wouldn't a true 'doesn't imply', 'there is no causal relation between', allow the variables to have *any* truth values with 'doesn't imply' still being true (or false, for that matter, or simply undefined, since it refers to relations beyond pure syntax)? Your first demonstration of how to get the conditional's truth table works well, but there's an issue with your second one: Why can't the last two rows be left undefined? One answer is that if we knew A⇒B is true and the last two rows were undefined or false we could deduce that A must be true. Similar problems arise if we let one be false and the other undefined (if the third row's undefined and the last row's false then A⇒B being false and B being false would allow us to deduce that A is false, which it clearly shouldn't; and vice versa).

The statement we are given (because we should somehow relate to it) is: “Phi does not imply psi if: even though phi is T, psi is nevertheless F.” This is not my natural (intuitive) understanding of “does not imply.” In normal usage, although phi “does not imply” psi, it does not preclude psi either--the usage is not exclusive. So thinking through this for hours, my intuitive grasp here relates to negation. I have a better sense of the cases when the antecedent is false leading to implication being true, than to “this does not imply that,” apparently. Thus building the full 'implies' truth table and then forming the negation of its conclusion yields the full “does not imply” truth table. I liked Hadrien’s Method 1: Rewording the implication truth table, but it left me hanging when I really dug into it. Yet KD is a mathematician, so perhaps I’m still not getting this “most difficult part of the entire course.”

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
This is a strange thread that seems to be totally off course. As I emphasized at the time, the material conditional is not a definition of implication. As I said, impaction is way too complicated to define within mathematics. Rather, the material conditional is a model for implication that exhibits some features of implication. So there is no question of whether it is 'right' or 'wrong'. Rather the issue is whether the conditional is appropriate or not to use in a given situation. I gave as an example where a professional community agrees that it is appropriate is in the design of computer reasoning systems, where you cannot have an undefined output. More generally, the consensus among mathematicians is that it is a pretty good model for many purposes within mathematics. In the lecture, I provided the rationale that lies behind the particular definition of the conditional. Again, that is not a proof, it is an analysis of implication from the perspective of truth values that leads to a particular definition being adopted. Though K-12 schools seem to leave people thinking that mathematics is all about right or wrong, that's actually not the case. Most mathematicians spend much of their time focusing on how to model real world phenomena. The metric there is not right or wrong -- that has no meaning -- rather on how appropriate is the model. Right or wrong questions apply only when you are working within a particular model, be that model arithmetic, planar Euclidean geometry, Riemannian geometry, general topology, or whatever. Mathematics courses usually focus on working within mathematics, so modeling issues rarely arise. But this is not a mathematics course, it is about mathematical thinking . This is also reflected in the fact that logical correctness is only one of several factors we take into account when evaluating mathematical arguments. For instance, those parameters of opening and closing are significant because they are the mathematical side of the input and output links to the context within which mathematics itself gets applied. (So they are part of the API, in computer programming terminology.) I hope this helps. One of the reason courses like this are called 'transition courses' is that they help high school graduates go beyond the rather narrow view of mathematics that the K-12 system seems to encourage.

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: to KD : I think your Lecture 3 on implication is plainly wrong !
Input.posts:
I had a lot of trouble understanding this lecture... I've spent days on it, trying to figure out why I had this strange feeling about it, why I couldn't integrate blindly these notions, why I couldn't move on to the next lecture, why I kept coming back to this one. I finally came to the conclusion that this lecture is plainly wrong, I think that I've found a lot of errors in it. Here is why : ===================== Definition of implication ===================== 'A implies B' I think the implication definition 'The truth of B follows from the truth of A' you gave in Lecture 3 is ambiguous. Upon the wanted meaning, there is a language ambiguity that carries an additional unwanted meaning : ' For B to be true, A has to be true in the first place' (or 'we can't have B true, if A is not true in the first place' ), which gives an erroneous information about the material conditional truth table case 'False ⇒ True' which (to be consistent with this undesirable meaning) would be 'False' instead of the correct 'True'. I'd rather use a reversed rewording of your definition : 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' , or even simplier : 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' . Both of these definitions are intuitive and doesn't carry the extra undesirable meaning that goes with the definition you provided. ==================================== Filling the material conditional truth table ==================================== As written earlier, 'A implies B' can be defined as 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' or as 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' , which leads to the following material conditional truth table : A B A ⇒ B ---------------------- T T T T F F F T ? (we have no intuition here) F F ? (we have no intuition here) First of all, I will expose the two methods I use to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table, then I'll explain why I disagree with the method you provided in Lecture 3. Method 1 : Rewording the implication definition Saying 'If A is true, then B is necessarly true' is equivalent to saying 'We can't have A true and B false'. This rephrasing can easily be expressed in logical operators as :'¬(A ∧ ¬B)', and the fact that the behaviours of these logical operators are well-known allows us to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table. A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ----------------------------- T T T T F F F T T F F T Method 2 : Identifying and eliminating the unsuitable truth table cases Let's write all of the possible combinations for the unintuitive cases. A B (1) (2) (3) (4) -------------------------------------------------- T T T T T T T F F F F F F T F T F T F F F F T T It's easily understandable that the implication has these two properties : implication is not trivial, implication is asymmetric. (1) This combination is the truth table of the conjonction '∧', and implication is not a conjonction, thus we can eliminate this column. We can also say that this combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. (2) This combination has the same truth table as 'B'. An implication is not trivial, it shouldn't be equivalent to its consequent, thus we can eliminate this column. (3) This combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. It's actually the truth table of the equivalence '⇔', but we can't use this fact here since the equivalence is defined upon the notion of implication wich we're still trying to complete at this moment. (4) By using this elimination process, and after checking that this combination is neither trivial nor asymmetric, and that it doesn't match the truth table of another already-known logical operator, we can finally conclude that this column is the only one suitable for the material conditional. ====================================================== The distinction between 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' ====================================================== During Lecture 3 (21:30 on the video timeline), you provide a method to fill the material conditional by using the definition of 'A doesn't imply B'. I think you're mistaken. Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration : Your exact words are : 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', and you claim that for all the other cases, we'll get 'False'. You've come to the 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement by refering to the 'True ⇒ False' case of the material conditional (which we know gives 'False', and become 'True' for the 'non-implication'), but you can't know at this stage that it's the only case of the material conditional that leads to 'False', therefore you can't know whether or not it's the only case that leads to 'True' for the 'non-implication'. And yet, you go on with your demonstration as if it was the case : you're using this 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement, which we don't know whether or not it captures the complete behaviour of 'not-implication', to fill the totality of the 'not-implication' truth table. My understanding is that we can't fill the totality of a truth table only by using a statement who doesn't encompass all the behaviours of the logical operator we're assessing. Actually it turns out that your statement encompass all the behaviours of 'not-implication', but at this stage of the demonstration we couldn't know it : you actually jumped to the conclusion without providing the valid demonstration to back it up. We can't use this method to fill our material conditional truth table. We had no intution for the implication and we have no intuition for the 'non-implication' neither. 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : And there is an even bigger, insidious, and mindboggling issue, which caused me to think a lot before I was able to spot it and formulate it. To fill the incomplete material conditional truth table, your intention was to use the definition of 'does not imply', you said so at two differents moments on the video : [21:30 on timeline] 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', [26:45 on timeline] 'The definition for a False antecedent is based on a truth value analysis of the notion 'does not imply''. But instead of using a 'doesn't imply' definition, you used a 'non-implication' demonstration, which has proved to be erroneous (hence my precedent title : Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration). I think that 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' doesn't express the meaning of 'A doesn't imply B' because it enforces a relationship between A and not-B (A has to be True and B has to be False) instead of expressing an absence of relationship. To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.

To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.

Largely agree Professor Devlin could've been more precise in his wording. Instead of 'does not imply' he could have said 'can not imply' or 'definitely does not imply' (which makes 'can not imply' useful for disproving implication). I agree that 'doesn't imply' only definitely implies no causal or logical relation between the contents of the variables. However, couldn't knowing that there's no causal relation (or none better than chance, relative to environmental randomness) be useful in modeling science and probability? Isolating independent variables is extremely important, even if we can't prove that one 'can not imply' the other (which would be better and stronger but not necessarily available). But wouldn't a true 'doesn't imply', 'there is no causal relation between', allow the variables to have *any* truth values with 'doesn't imply' still being true (or false, for that matter, or simply undefined, since it refers to relations beyond pure syntax)? Your first demonstration of how to get the conditional's truth table works well, but there's an issue with your second one: Why can't the last two rows be left undefined? One answer is that if we knew A⇒B is true and the last two rows were undefined or false we could deduce that A must be true. Similar problems arise if we let one be false and the other undefined (if the third row's undefined and the last row's false then A⇒B being false and B being false would allow us to deduce that A is false, which it clearly shouldn't; and vice versa).

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
This is a strange thread that seems to be totally off course. As I emphasized at the time, the material conditional is not a definition of implication. As I said, impaction is way too complicated to define within mathematics. Rather, the material conditional is a model for implication that exhibits some features of implication. So there is no question of whether it is 'right' or 'wrong'. Rather the issue is whether the conditional is appropriate or not to use in a given situation. I gave as an example where a professional community agrees that it is appropriate is in the design of computer reasoning systems, where you cannot have an undefined output. More generally, the consensus among mathematicians is that it is a pretty good model for many purposes within mathematics. In the lecture, I provided the rationale that lies behind the particular definition of the conditional. Again, that is not a proof, it is an analysis of implication from the perspective of truth values that leads to a particular definition being adopted. Though K-12 schools seem to leave people thinking that mathematics is all about right or wrong, that's actually not the case. Most mathematicians spend much of their time focusing on how to model real world phenomena. The metric there is not right or wrong -- that has no meaning -- rather on how appropriate is the model. Right or wrong questions apply only when you are working within a particular model, be that model arithmetic, planar Euclidean geometry, Riemannian geometry, general topology, or whatever. Mathematics courses usually focus on working within mathematics, so modeling issues rarely arise. But this is not a mathematics course, it is about mathematical thinking . This is also reflected in the fact that logical correctness is only one of several factors we take into account when evaluating mathematical arguments. For instance, those parameters of opening and closing are significant because they are the mathematical side of the input and output links to the context within which mathematics itself gets applied. (So they are part of the API, in computer programming terminology.) I hope this helps. One of the reason courses like this are called 'transition courses' is that they help high school graduates go beyond the rather narrow view of mathematics that the K-12 system seems to encourage.
