Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: to KD : I think your Lecture 3 on implication is plainly wrong !
Input.posts:
I had a lot of trouble understanding this lecture... I've spent days on it, trying to figure out why I had this strange feeling about it, why I couldn't integrate blindly these notions, why I couldn't move on to the next lecture, why I kept coming back to this one. I finally came to the conclusion that this lecture is plainly wrong, I think that I've found a lot of errors in it. Here is why : ===================== Definition of implication ===================== 'A implies B' I think the implication definition 'The truth of B follows from the truth of A' you gave in Lecture 3 is ambiguous. Upon the wanted meaning, there is a language ambiguity that carries an additional unwanted meaning : ' For B to be true, A has to be true in the first place' (or 'we can't have B true, if A is not true in the first place' ), which gives an erroneous information about the material conditional truth table case 'False ⇒ True' which (to be consistent with this undesirable meaning) would be 'False' instead of the correct 'True'. I'd rather use a reversed rewording of your definition : 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' , or even simplier : 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' . Both of these definitions are intuitive and doesn't carry the extra undesirable meaning that goes with the definition you provided. ==================================== Filling the material conditional truth table ==================================== As written earlier, 'A implies B' can be defined as 'From the truth of A follows the truth of B' or as 'If A is true, then B is (necessarily) true' , which leads to the following material conditional truth table : A B A ⇒ B ---------------------- T T T T F F F T ? (we have no intuition here) F F ? (we have no intuition here) First of all, I will expose the two methods I use to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table, then I'll explain why I disagree with the method you provided in Lecture 3. Method 1 : Rewording the implication definition Saying 'If A is true, then B is necessarly true' is equivalent to saying 'We can't have A true and B false'. This rephrasing can easily be expressed in logical operators as :'¬(A ∧ ¬B)', and the fact that the behaviours of these logical operators are well-known allows us to fill the totality of the material conditional truth table. A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ----------------------------- T T T T F F F T T F F T Method 2 : Identifying and eliminating the unsuitable truth table cases Let's write all of the possible combinations for the unintuitive cases. A B (1) (2) (3) (4) -------------------------------------------------- T T T T T T T F F F F F F T F T F T F F F F T T It's easily understandable that the implication has these two properties : implication is not trivial, implication is asymmetric. (1) This combination is the truth table of the conjonction '∧', and implication is not a conjonction, thus we can eliminate this column. We can also say that this combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. (2) This combination has the same truth table as 'B'. An implication is not trivial, it shouldn't be equivalent to its consequent, thus we can eliminate this column. (3) This combination has a property of symmetry that an implication shouldn't have : 'A ⇒ B' give the same values as 'B ⇒ A', wich again makes this column unsuitable. It's actually the truth table of the equivalence '⇔', but we can't use this fact here since the equivalence is defined upon the notion of implication wich we're still trying to complete at this moment. (4) By using this elimination process, and after checking that this combination is neither trivial nor asymmetric, and that it doesn't match the truth table of another already-known logical operator, we can finally conclude that this column is the only one suitable for the material conditional. ====================================================== The distinction between 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' ====================================================== During Lecture 3 (21:30 on the video timeline), you provide a method to fill the material conditional by using the definition of 'A doesn't imply B'. I think you're mistaken. Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration : Your exact words are : 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', and you claim that for all the other cases, we'll get 'False'. You've come to the 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement by refering to the 'True ⇒ False' case of the material conditional (which we know gives 'False', and become 'True' for the 'non-implication'), but you can't know at this stage that it's the only case of the material conditional that leads to 'False', therefore you can't know whether or not it's the only case that leads to 'True' for the 'non-implication'. And yet, you go on with your demonstration as if it was the case : you're using this 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' statement, which we don't know whether or not it captures the complete behaviour of 'not-implication', to fill the totality of the 'not-implication' truth table. My understanding is that we can't fill the totality of a truth table only by using a statement who doesn't encompass all the behaviours of the logical operator we're assessing. Actually it turns out that your statement encompass all the behaviours of 'not-implication', but at this stage of the demonstration we couldn't know it : you actually jumped to the conclusion without providing the valid demonstration to back it up. We can't use this method to fill our material conditional truth table. We had no intution for the implication and we have no intuition for the 'non-implication' neither. 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : And there is an even bigger, insidious, and mindboggling issue, which caused me to think a lot before I was able to spot it and formulate it. To fill the incomplete material conditional truth table, your intention was to use the definition of 'does not imply', you said so at two differents moments on the video : [21:30 on timeline] 'A doesn't imply B if : Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false', [26:45 on timeline] 'The definition for a False antecedent is based on a truth value analysis of the notion 'does not imply''. But instead of using a 'doesn't imply' definition, you used a 'non-implication' demonstration, which has proved to be erroneous (hence my precedent title : Erroneous 'not-implication' demonstration). I think that 'Even though A is true, B is nevertheless false' doesn't express the meaning of 'A doesn't imply B' because it enforces a relationship between A and not-B (A has to be True and B has to be False) instead of expressing an absence of relationship. To my mind, 'A doesn't imply B' means that there is no causality relationship between the antecedent A and the consequent B, and this absence of relationship can be formulated in several ways : We can have A True and B true, or A True and B False : (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) It's not the case that 'if A is True, B has to be True as well', or that 'if A is True, then B has to be False as well' : ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) ≡ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ∨ ¬¬(A ∧ ¬¬B) ≡ (A ∧ ¬B) ∨ (A ∧ B) A B (A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B) ¬(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- T T T T T F T T F T F F F F F F Notice that '(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ ¬B)' and '(A ⇒ B) ∨ ¬(A ⇒ ¬B)' have the same truth values as 'A', which means that these 'A doesn't imply B' statements are trivial, and I think it's exactly what we intuitively expect from an absence of relationship : it's logically trivial. Therefore, 'doesn't imply' and 'not-implication' are two different things : 'doesn't imply' is logicaly trivial and doesn't seem to be useful whatsoever, 'not-implication' can't be used to fill the material conditional as I've shown previously, because to formulate the 'not-implication', you first have to find the 'implication' definition ¬(A ∧ ¬B), and only afterwards you can derivate from it to get the 'not-implication' definition ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B). A B ¬(A ∧ ¬B) ¬¬(A ∧ ¬B) ------------------------------------------------- T T T F T F F T F T T F F F T F From this truth table, I can see that 'not-implication' has usefulness : it gives a method for 'proving that an implication is False'. Which is (according to the truth table) by showing that the antecedent of an implication is True while its consequent is False.

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: why does KD's proof for rows 3 and 4 make sense?
Input.posts:
For proving that rows 3 and 4 in the truth table, he tells us we cannot use $$phi => Ψ$$ because we have no intuition of using False as the antecedent. To overcome this obstacle he tells us to look at $$phi \neq> Ψ$$ but aren't we in the same boat regardless because we again don't know what will happen if we have false as the antecedent. Moreover, he states that the only way to make this condition true is if phi is true and Ψ is false therefore every other combination of true/false must equate to a false condition. But how does he know that is the only way to make the statement true since we have no intuition of what occurs when we put false in as the antecedent. To make it more clear about what I am talking about, Here it the truth table: Row phi Ψ phi=> Ψ 1 T T T 2 T F F 3 F T T 4 F F T

Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: why does KD's proof for rows 3 and 4 make sense?
Input.posts:
For proving that rows 3 and 4 in the truth table, he tells us we cannot use $$phi => Ψ$$ because we have no intuition of using False as the antecedent. To overcome this obstacle he tells us to look at $$phi \neq> Ψ$$ but aren't we in the same boat regardless because we again don't know what will happen if we have false as the antecedent. Moreover, he states that the only way to make this condition true is if phi is true and Ψ is false therefore every other combination of true/false must equate to a false condition. But how does he know that is the only way to make the statement true since we have no intuition of what occurs when we put false in as the antecedent. To make it more clear about what I am talking about, Here it the truth table: Row phi Ψ phi=> Ψ 1 T T T 2 T F F 3 F T T 4 F F T

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Implication Truth-Table: Last two rows
Input.posts:
I follow the logic in the lecture concerning the first two rows for both the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation and the $$\phi \not\implies \psi$$ relations. Those two rows are understandable and consistent. But it seems the last two rows are (arbitrarily) defined, but not rationalized. Why not say that if $$\phi$$ is false then $$\phi \not \implies \psi$$ is always true. That is a false antecedent does not imply any consequent. Then the negation of that would make the last two rows of the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation false instead of true? I am sure I must have missed something key...what was it?
Upvotes:
5
I think the very fact that you can't conclude anything is what makes it make sense. You can't say the implication is false, because what can you conclude from a false antecedent? Nothing. So since we're leaving out causation, they're true. And the logic in the lecture (which is much better than my handwaving) is that there is only *one* condition under which phi does not imply psi is true, where phi is true and psi is false. All other cases are false, because if phi is false you can't conclude anything about psi. That means in the opposite condition we must have one false, and the rest true.

I think for some people it 'doesn't feel right' to fill in the last rows with Ts because they think: 'I don't know anything about psi if phi is false, so I leave it blank (or put question marks in there)'. The problem would be that a computer can't 'put a question mark in there', it only knows zeros and ones, so it has to make a decision (or alternatively, warn the programmer that there is not enough information to do the calculation correctly and demand more input, which would be much better and safer) So it has to make a 'strategic decision', *until* it gets additional information about what happens if psi is true (or false). I think to fill in the last rows with T makes a lot more sense as soon as we try to combine our implication 'phi implies psi' with a second, 'reverse' implication like 'psi implies phi' or 'not psi implies phi' using conjunction and/or disjunction, where the 'reverse' implication might contradict our original implication, if we put F in one or both of the rows. Here's how I understand it. The key is in considering genuine implication' - it has a notion of causality (mathematical implication does not), i.e. one thing, the antecedent, causes another thing, the consequent. We often use it in daily life. 'If I'm thirsty, I will have a glass of water' is an instance of a genuine implication. We can analyze it if the antecedent 'I'm thirsty' is true. If I'm thirsty and going to have some water, the implication is true - its antecedent is true, so is the consequent ('I will have a glass of water'). In this case the genuine implication holds. But if I'm thirsty and not going to drink some water, it doesn't. Now the genuine implication is false. If the antecedent is false, the genuine implication makes no sense (there's nothing to put a causal relation on). To construct a mathematical notion of implication, we need to define it for the cases in which the antecedent is false. Let's treat genuine implication as a logical operation. We already have two cases representing the relation between the antecedent and the consequent depending on their values - if they are both true, implication holds, if only the first one is true, it is not. But if it is not, then the negation, 'non-implication', must be true. According to genuine implication, it is the only sensible way when non-implication can be true. So the rest three cases of non-implication are considered false. And since implication is the negation of non-implication, we get the truth table as in the lecture. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

So it follows from saying that the truth table of the negation of z will be equivalent to z but with every T and F reversed. We know what not(x->y) is for when x is T, which must be the value for (x->y) when X is F. It's like assuming symmetry and completeness. Does this mean negation is distributive across the truth function (the function that assigns T or F to each variable)? But negation isn't distributive across the logical operators: not(x&y) isn't equivalent to (not x) & (not y). But if we also applied 'not' to 'and' to construct 'not-and' (which would have the reverse truth table of 'and', so it would only be true when both x and y are false), then it is distributive! not(x&y) = (not x) (not &) (not y)

I also had been having trouble understanding the rationale for the last two rows, so I Googled 'explanation of truth table for implication' and found this: To understand why this table is the way it is, consider the following example: 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' The statement will be true if I keep my promise and false if I don't. Suppose it's true that you get an A and it's true that I give you a dollar. Since I kept my promise, the implication is True . This corresponds to the first line in the table. Suppose it's true that you get an A but it's false that I give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is False . This corresponds to the second line in the table. What if it's false that you get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can't be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table. Explained this way, I (finally) got it and what Keith said about separating the causation part from the truth or conditional part of implication made sense! Another help, frankly, was the use of the letters P and Q instead of the symbols. For some reason, having to read or write (using the inclusive 'or', lol) was getting in the way of my understanding the material.

The tricky part is understanding what we lose from our intuitive understanding of implication when we give up causation. Taking Donna's implication, 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' , When the antecedent is False then you never get to test my integrity. But, does that imply that the conditional is now necessarily true? Does that imply that I was definitely going to give you that dollar if you got the A? Intuitively I would say that it does not. I could have decided to never give you that dollar, regardless. Similarly, If I say 'If you are abused as a child then you will become a criminal.', but, you weren't abused, the can we say that my above stated relationship is true? Clearly not. And therein, (at least for me) lay the confusion, because this is exactly what we give up when we give up causation. Understanding this, made it easier to grasp.

What would happen if the last two rows were false instead of true? That would just make it another, different logical operator. Apparently '->' is more useful in mathematical contexts. When modeling the 'truth' part of implication, we wouldn't want to rule out potentially true implications in cases where it can't be decided yet. So it's like saying 'all except those cases where the implication is definitely false' will be true, or as good as true. Also, something similar already follows from saying that 'not all cars are badly made' is equivalent to 'at least one car is not badly made'. As discussed in a prior thread, it follows that if no instances of x exist, then 'all x are y' is true for all y, which is similar to saying x->y is true whenever x is false. Then again, x not existing and x being false aren't quite the same. Maybe it has to do with the connection between number theory and real number geometry, since we wouldn't want any gaps in the number line. Also, as Devlin says in explaining the conditional, we want '~' to always flip true and false... perhaps that's related to symmetry, a useful property. Devlin also says mathematicians don't like to leave things undefined, so it's worth extending the definition. That same reasoning, extending the Riemann Zeta function to cases outside its original domain, is how mathematicians got 'the zeta-regularized sum of the natural numbers = - 1 / 12', which has proven extremely useful in physics.

Maybe this definition of the conditional is more useful because it allows us to *disprove* 'x implies y', and perhaps it's also useful for proof by contradiction. I think Devlin mentions that 'x->y' is only false when 'x implies y' is also false, and that means that if we can prove x->y is false, then 'x implies y' is also false. But if we had made the last two rows of the truth table false, then there would be cases where x->y would be false but 'x implies y' could be true (since x being false and y being true or false tells us nothing about whether x implies y or not). So making the last two rows false is more useful for proving things about genuine implication.

Suppose we left the last two rows undefined or false. Then x->y would only be true when x is true. So if we know x->y is true, it follows that x must be true... and hence that y is true too. But we don't want to be able to conclude from 'x implies y' is true that x is true and y is true, because that's not true about 'x implies y'. And it 'breaks' the proof system, or at least would make x->y non-useful because it would just = x&y.
Upvotes:
0
That's only if *both* the last two rows are undefined or false. But if either of them were false, there would be cases where x->y is false but 'x implies y' is true (we can't conclude anything about 'x implies y' from cases where x is false). So neither of the last two rows can be false, and they can't both be undefined or non-true. Suppose row 3 were true and row 4 undefined. Then it would follow that if x->y is true and x is false, y must be true... but that clearly doesn't follow from 'x implies y'. Likewise, if row 3 were undefined and row 4 true, we could conclude from x->y is true and x is false that y is false, which again doesn't follow from 'x implies y'.

Thanks to everyone who contributed to this thread. It was a good discussion. Since I started the thread I thought I would summarize what you all taught me. First, if $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ is a causal implication , (not just a conditional of non-causally-related statements) then if the first two rows of the truth table are accepted then the next two rows can be accepted since $$\phi = FALSE$$ does not invalidate (and is not inconsistent with) the causal link established in the first two rows. The example I liked the best as a demonstration of this was the implication 'If it rains tomorrow, then I will go to the theater.' If tomorrow it is sunny, then I do not do any damage to the implication by going or not going to the theater. Second, In the case of a pure (non-causal) conditional $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, I am happy to accept the truth table as a definition by mathematicians that works for maintaining valid reasoning when applied in the context of a mathematical proof. In this case it is not necessary to worry about whether or not the relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$ makes sense since there is no relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$. Again, thanks to all who participated.

Hey Robin, I go way back in programming too. I learned BASIC and then programmed in PL/1. By far, the most fun language of all was APL (A Programming Language). I programmed in APL until I left my job around 1990. I believe you are looking at the truth value of the implication in the wrong way. Let's look at your second example since it does not have the else (or first ex and remove the else). In your program, if the machine went haywire and the action failed to execute even though the IF was True, then we would say the implication was false. If the IF was false and the action did not occur, then the code was good. Now, suppose: 1. you had a line of code initializing the variable A to 0 and variable B to 0. 2. you had an if/then statement later that says If A>0, then set B to 0. 3. in #2, the IF condition is false, and the B condition is True. And the code was still good. It worked the way it was supposed to work. Hope that helps.,
Instructor's post : Hey Robin, I go way back in programming too. I learned BASIC and then programmed in PL/1. By far, the most fun language of all was APL (A Programming Language). I programmed in APL until I left my job around 1990. I believe you are looking at the truth value of the implication in the wrong way. Let's look at your second example since it does not have the else (or first ex and remove the else). In your program, if the machine went haywire and the action failed to execute even though the IF was True, then we would say the implication was false. If the IF was false and the action did not occur, then the code was good. Now, suppose: 1. you had a line of code initializing the variable A to 0 and variable B to 0. 2. you had an if/then statement later that says If A>0, then set B to 0. 3. in #2, the IF condition is false, and the B condition is True. And the code was still good. It worked the way it was supposed to work. Hope that helps.,

Input.threadtitle: Implication Truth-Table: Last two rows
Input.posts:
I follow the logic in the lecture concerning the first two rows for both the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation and the $$\phi \not\implies \psi$$ relations. Those two rows are understandable and consistent. But it seems the last two rows are (arbitrarily) defined, but not rationalized. Why not say that if $$\phi$$ is false then $$\phi \not \implies \psi$$ is always true. That is a false antecedent does not imply any consequent. Then the negation of that would make the last two rows of the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation false instead of true? I am sure I must have missed something key...what was it?
Upvotes:
5
I think the very fact that you can't conclude anything is what makes it make sense. You can't say the implication is false, because what can you conclude from a false antecedent? Nothing. So since we're leaving out causation, they're true. And the logic in the lecture (which is much better than my handwaving) is that there is only *one* condition under which phi does not imply psi is true, where phi is true and psi is false. All other cases are false, because if phi is false you can't conclude anything about psi. That means in the opposite condition we must have one false, and the rest true.

Here's how I understand it. The key is in considering genuine implication' - it has a notion of causality (mathematical implication does not), i.e. one thing, the antecedent, causes another thing, the consequent. We often use it in daily life. 'If I'm thirsty, I will have a glass of water' is an instance of a genuine implication. We can analyze it if the antecedent 'I'm thirsty' is true. If I'm thirsty and going to have some water, the implication is true - its antecedent is true, so is the consequent ('I will have a glass of water'). In this case the genuine implication holds. But if I'm thirsty and not going to drink some water, it doesn't. Now the genuine implication is false. If the antecedent is false, the genuine implication makes no sense (there's nothing to put a causal relation on). To construct a mathematical notion of implication, we need to define it for the cases in which the antecedent is false. Let's treat genuine implication as a logical operation. We already have two cases representing the relation between the antecedent and the consequent depending on their values - if they are both true, implication holds, if only the first one is true, it is not. But if it is not, then the negation, 'non-implication', must be true. According to genuine implication, it is the only sensible way when non-implication can be true. So the rest three cases of non-implication are considered false. And since implication is the negation of non-implication, we get the truth table as in the lecture. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

So it follows from saying that the truth table of the negation of z will be equivalent to z but with every T and F reversed. We know what not(x->y) is for when x is T, which must be the value for (x->y) when X is F. It's like assuming symmetry and completeness. Does this mean negation is distributive across the truth function (the function that assigns T or F to each variable)? But negation isn't distributive across the logical operators: not(x&y) isn't equivalent to (not x) & (not y). But if we also applied 'not' to 'and' to construct 'not-and' (which would have the reverse truth table of 'and', so it would only be true when both x and y are false), then it is distributive! not(x&y) = (not x) (not &) (not y)

I also had been having trouble understanding the rationale for the last two rows, so I Googled 'explanation of truth table for implication' and found this: To understand why this table is the way it is, consider the following example: 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' The statement will be true if I keep my promise and false if I don't. Suppose it's true that you get an A and it's true that I give you a dollar. Since I kept my promise, the implication is True . This corresponds to the first line in the table. Suppose it's true that you get an A but it's false that I give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is False . This corresponds to the second line in the table. What if it's false that you get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can't be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table. Explained this way, I (finally) got it and what Keith said about separating the causation part from the truth or conditional part of implication made sense! Another help, frankly, was the use of the letters P and Q instead of the symbols. For some reason, having to read or write (using the inclusive 'or', lol) was getting in the way of my understanding the material.

What would happen if the last two rows were false instead of true? That would just make it another, different logical operator. Apparently '->' is more useful in mathematical contexts. When modeling the 'truth' part of implication, we wouldn't want to rule out potentially true implications in cases where it can't be decided yet. Then again, x not existing and x being false aren't quite the same. Maybe it has to do with the connection between number theory and real number geometry, since we wouldn't want any gaps in the number line. Also, as Devlin says in explaining the conditional, we want '~' to always flip true and false... perhaps that's related to symmetry, a useful property. Devlin also says mathematicians don't like to leave things undefined, so it's worth extending the definition. That same reasoning, extending the Riemann Zeta function to cases outside its original domain, is how mathematicians got 'the zeta-regularized sum of the natural numbers = - 1 / 12', which has proven extremely useful in physics.

Suppose we left the last two rows undefined or false. Then x->y would only be true when x is true. So if we know x->y is true, it follows that x must be true... and hence that y is true too. But we don't want to be able to conclude from 'x implies y' is true that x is true and y is true, because that's not true about 'x implies y'. Upvotes:

That's only if *both* the last two rows are undefined or false. But if either of them were false, there would be cases where x->y is false but 'x implies y' is true (we can't conclude anything about 'x implies y' from cases where x is false). So neither of the last two rows can be false, and they can't both be undefined or non-true. Suppose row 3 were true and row 4 undefined. Then it would follow that if x->y is true and x is false, y must be true... but that clearly doesn't follow from 'x implies y'. Likewise, if row 3 were undefined and row 4 true, we could conclude from x->y is true and x is false that y is false, which again doesn't follow from 'x implies y'.

Thanks to everyone who contributed to this thread. It was a good discussion. Since I started the thread I thought I would summarize what you all taught me. First, if $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ is a causal implication , (not just a conditional of non-causally-related statements) then if the first two rows of the truth table are accepted then the next two rows can be accepted since $$\phi = FALSE$$ does not invalidate (and is not inconsistent with) the causal link established in the first two rows. The example I liked the best as a demonstration of this was the implication 'If it rains tomorrow, then I will go to the theater.' If tomorrow it is sunny, then I do not do any damage to the implication by going or not going to the theater. Second, In the case of a pure (non-causal) conditional $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, I am happy to accept the truth table as a definition by mathematicians that works for maintaining valid reasoning when applied in the context of a mathematical proof. In this case it is not necessary to worry about whether or not the relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$ makes sense since there is no relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$. Again, thanks to all who participated.

Here's how I understand it. The key is in considering genuine implication' - it has a notion of causality (mathematical implication does not), i.e. one thing, the antecedent, causes another thing, the consequent. We often use it in daily life. 'If I'm thirsty, I will have a glass of water' is an instance of a genuine implication. We can analyze it if the antecedent 'I'm thirsty' is true. If I'm thirsty and going to have some water, the implication is true - its antecedent is true, so is the consequent ('I will have a glass of water'). In this case the genuine implication holds. But if I'm thirsty and not going to drink some water, it doesn't. Now the genuine implication is false. If the antecedent is false, the genuine implication makes no sense (there's nothing to put a causal relation on). To construct a mathematical notion of implication, we need to define it for the cases in which the antecedent is false. Let's treat genuine implication as a logical operation. We already have two cases representing the relation between the antecedent and the consequent depending on their values - if they are both true, implication holds, if only the first one is true, it is not. But if it is not, then the negation, 'non-implication', must be true. According to genuine implication, it is the only sensible way when non-implication can be true. So the rest three cases of non-implication are considered false. And since implication is the negation of non-implication, we get the truth table as in the lecture. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

So it follows from saying that the truth table of the negation of z will be equivalent to z but with every T and F reversed. We know what not(x->y) is for when x is T, which must be the value for (x->y) when X is F. It's like assuming symmetry and completeness. Does this mean negation is distributive across the truth function (the function that assigns T or F to each variable)? But negation isn't distributive across the logical operators: not(x&y) isn't equivalent to (not x) & (not y). But if we also applied 'not' to 'and' to construct 'not-and' (which would have the reverse truth table of 'and', so it would only be true when both x and y are false), then it is distributive! not(x&y) = (not x) (not &) (not y)

I also had been having trouble understanding the rationale for the last two rows, so I Googled 'explanation of truth table for implication' and found this: To understand why this table is the way it is, consider the following example: 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' The statement will be true if I keep my promise and false if I don't. Suppose it's true that you get an A and it's true that I give you a dollar. Since I kept my promise, the implication is True . This corresponds to the first line in the table. Suppose it's true that you get an A but it's false that I give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is False . This corresponds to the second line in the table. What if it's false that you get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can't be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table. Explained this way, I (finally) got it and what Keith said about separating the causation part from the truth or conditional part of implication made sense! Another help, frankly, was the use of the letters P and Q instead of the symbols. For some reason, having to read or write (using the inclusive 'or', lol) was getting in the way of my understanding the material.

Taking Donna's implication, 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' , When the antecedent is False then you never get to test my integrity. What would happen if the last two rows were false instead of true? That would just make it another, different logical operator. Apparently '->' is more useful in mathematical contexts. When modeling the 'truth' part of implication, we wouldn't want to rule out potentially true implications in cases where it can't be decided yet. So it's like saying 'all except those cases where the implication is definitely false' will be true, or as good as true. Also, something similar already follows from saying that 'not all cars are badly made' is equivalent to 'at least one car is not badly made'. As discussed in a prior thread, it follows that if no instances of x exist, then 'all x are y' is true for all y, which is similar to saying x->y is true whenever x is false. Then again, x not existing and x being false aren't quite the same. Maybe it has to do with the connection between number theory and real number geometry, since we wouldn't want any gaps in the number line. Also, as Devlin says in explaining the conditional, we want '~' to always flip true and false... perhaps that's related to symmetry, a useful property. Devlin also says mathematicians don't like to leave things undefined, so it's worth extending the definition. That same reasoning, extending the Riemann Zeta function to cases outside its original domain, is how mathematicians got 'the zeta-regularized sum of the natural numbers = - 1 / 12', which has proven extremely useful in physics.

Maybe this definition of the conditional is more useful because it allows us to *disprove* 'x implies y', and perhaps it's also useful for proof by contradiction. I think Devlin mentions that 'x->y' is only false when 'x implies y' is also false, and that means that if we can prove x->y is false, then 'x implies y' is also false. But if we had made the last two rows of the truth table false, then there would be cases where x->y would be false but 'x implies y' could be true (since x being false and y being true or false tells us nothing about whether x implies y or not). So making the last two rows false is more useful for proving things about genuine implication.

Suppose we left the last two rows undefined or false. Then x->y would only be true when x is true. So if we know x->y is true, it follows that x must be true... and hence that y is true too. But we don't want to be able to conclude from 'x implies y' is true that x is true and y is true, because that's not true about 'x implies y'. And it 'breaks' the proof system, or at least would make x->y non-useful because it would just = x&y.
Upvotes:
0
That's only if *both* the last two rows are undefined or false. But if either of them were false, there would be cases where x->y is false but 'x implies y' is true (we can't conclude anything about 'x implies y' from cases where x is false). So neither of the last two rows can be false, and they can't both be undefined or non-true. Suppose row 3 were true and row 4 undefined. Then it would follow that if x->y is true and x is false, y must be true... but that clearly doesn't follow from 'x implies y'. Likewise, if row 3 were undefined and row 4 true, we could conclude from x->y is true and x is false that y is false, which again doesn't follow from 'x implies y'.

Thanks to everyone who contributed to this thread. It was a good discussion. Since I started the thread I thought I would summarize what you all taught me. First, if $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ is a causal implication , (not just a conditional of non-causally-related statements) then if the first two rows of the truth table are accepted then the next two rows can be accepted since $$\phi = FALSE$$ does not invalidate (and is not inconsistent with) the causal link established in the first two rows. The example I liked the best as a demonstration of this was the implication 'If it rains tomorrow, then I will go to the theater.' If tomorrow it is sunny, then I do not do any damage to the implication by going or not going to the theater. Second, In the case of a pure (non-causal) conditional $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, I am happy to accept the truth table as a definition by mathematicians that works for maintaining valid reasoning when applied in the context of a mathematical proof. In this case it is not necessary to worry about whether or not the relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$ makes sense since there is no relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$. Again, thanks to all who participated.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hey Robin, I go way back in programming too. I learned BASIC and then programmed in PL/1. By far, the most fun language of all was APL (A Programming Language). I programmed in APL until I left my job around 1990. I believe you are looking at the truth value of the implication in the wrong way. Let's look at your second example since it does not have the else (or first ex and remove the else). In your program, if the machine went haywire and the action failed to execute even though the IF was True, then we would say the implication was false. If the IF was false and the action did not occur, then the code was good. Now, suppose: 1. you had a line of code initializing the variable A to 0 and variable B to 0. 2. you had an if/then statement later that says If A>0, then set B to 0. 3. in #2, the IF condition is false, and the B condition is True. And the code was still good. It worked the way it was supposed to work. Hope that helps.,

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Implication Truth-Table: Last two rows
Input.posts:
I follow the logic in the lecture concerning the first two rows for both the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation and the $$\phi \not\implies \psi$$ relations. Those two rows are understandable and consistent. But it seems the last two rows are (arbitrarily) defined, but not rationalized. Why not say that if $$\phi$$ is false then $$\phi \not \implies \psi$$ is always true. That is a false antecedent does not imply any consequent. Then the negation of that would make the last two rows of the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation false instead of true? I am sure I must have missed something key...what was it?
Upvotes:
5
I think the very fact that you can't conclude anything is what makes it make sense. You can't say the implication is false, because what can you conclude from a false antecedent? Nothing. So since we're leaving out causation, they're true. And the logic in the lecture (which is much better than my handwaving) is that there is only *one* condition under which phi does not imply psi is true, where phi is true and psi is false. All other cases are false, because if phi is false you can't conclude anything about psi. That means in the opposite condition we must have one false, and the rest true.

I think to fill in the last rows with T makes a lot more sense as soon as we try to combine our implication 'phi implies psi' with a second, 'reverse' implication like 'psi implies phi' or 'not psi implies phi' using conjunction and/or disjunction, where the 'reverse' implication might contradict our original implication, if we put F in one or both of the rows. Anyway, I'll have to think about this a little bit more.

Here's how I understand it. The key is in considering genuine implication' - it has a notion of causality (mathematical implication does not), i.e. one thing, the antecedent, causes another thing, the consequent. We often use it in daily life. 'If I'm thirsty, I will have a glass of water' is an instance of a genuine implication. We can analyze it if the antecedent 'I'm thirsty' is true. If I'm thirsty and going to have some water, the implication is true - its antecedent is true, so is the consequent ('I will have a glass of water'). In this case the genuine implication holds. But if I'm thirsty and not going to drink some water, it doesn't. Now the genuine implication is false. If the antecedent is false, the genuine implication makes no sense (there's nothing to put a causal relation on). To construct a mathematical notion of implication, we need to define it for the cases in which the antecedent is false. Let's treat genuine implication as a logical operation. We already have two cases representing the relation between the antecedent and the consequent depending on their values - if they are both true, implication holds, if only the first one is true, it is not. But if it is not, then the negation, 'non-implication', must be true. According to genuine implication, it is the only sensible way when non-implication can be true. So the rest three cases of non-implication are considered false. And since implication is the negation of non-implication, we get the truth table as in the lecture. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

So it follows from saying that the truth table of the negation of z will be equivalent to z but with every T and F reversed. We know what not(x->y) is for when x is T, which must be the value for (x->y) when X is F. It's like assuming symmetry and completeness. Does this mean negation is distributive across the truth function (the function that assigns T or F to each variable)? But negation isn't distributive across the logical operators: not(x&y) isn't equivalent to (not x) & (not y). But if we also applied 'not' to 'and' to construct 'not-and' (which would have the reverse truth table of 'and', so it would only be true when both x and y are false), then it is distributive! not(x&y) = (not x) (not &) (not y)

I also had been having trouble understanding the rationale for the last two rows, so I Googled 'explanation of truth table for implication' and found this: To understand why this table is the way it is, consider the following example: 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' The statement will be true if I keep my promise and false if I don't. Suppose it's true that you get an A and it's true that I give you a dollar. Since I kept my promise, the implication is True . This corresponds to the first line in the table. Suppose it's true that you get an A but it's false that I give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is False . This corresponds to the second line in the table. What if it's false that you get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can't be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table. Explained this way, I (finally) got it and what Keith said about separating the causation part from the truth or conditional part of implication made sense! What would happen if the last two rows were false instead of true? That would just make it another, different logical operator. Apparently '->' is more useful in mathematical contexts. Devlin also says mathematicians don't like to leave things undefined, so it's worth extending the definition. Suppose we left the last two rows undefined or false. Then x->y would only be true when x is true. So if we know x->y is true, it follows that x must be true... and hence that y is true too. But we don't want to be able to conclude from 'x implies y' is true that x is true and y is true, because that's not true about 'x implies y'. And it 'breaks' the proof system, or at least would make x->y non-useful because it would just = x&y.
Upvotes:
0
That's only if *both* the last two rows are undefined or false. But if either of them were false, there would be cases where x->y is false but 'x implies y' is true (we can't conclude anything about 'x implies y' from cases where x is false). So neither of the last two rows can be false, and they can't both be undefined or non-true. Suppose row 3 were true and row 4 undefined. Then it would follow that if x->y is true and x is false, y must be true... but that clearly doesn't follow from 'x implies y'. Likewise, if row 3 were undefined and row 4 true, we could conclude from x->y is true and x is false that y is false, which again doesn't follow from 'x implies y'.

Thanks to everyone who contributed to this thread. It was a good discussion. Since I started the thread I thought I would summarize what you all taught me. First, if $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ is a causal implication , (not just a conditional of non-causally-related statements) then if the first two rows of the truth table are accepted then the next two rows can be accepted since $$\phi = FALSE$$ does not invalidate (and is not inconsistent with) the causal link established in the first two rows. The example I liked the best as a demonstration of this was the implication 'If it rains tomorrow, then I will go to the theater.' If tomorrow it is sunny, then I do not do any damage to the implication by going or not going to the theater. Second, In the case of a pure (non-causal) conditional $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, I am happy to accept the truth table as a definition by mathematicians that works for maintaining valid reasoning when applied in the context of a mathematical proof. In this case it is not necessary to worry about whether or not the relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$ makes sense since there is no relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$. Again, thanks to all who participated.

Instructor's Post
Hey Robin, I go way back in programming too. I learned BASIC and then programmed in PL/1. By far, the most fun language of all was APL (A Programming Language). I programmed in APL until I left my job around 1990. I believe you are looking at the truth value of the implication in the wrong way. Let's look at your second example since it does not have the else (or first ex and remove the else). In your program, if the machine went haywire and the action failed to execute even though the IF was True, then we would say the implication was false. If the IF was false and the action did not occur, then the code was good. Now, suppose: 1. you had a line of code initializing the variable A to 0 and variable B to 0. 2. you had an if/then statement later that says If A>0, then set B to 0. 3. in #2, the IF condition is false, and the B condition is True. And the code was still good. It worked the way it was supposed to work. Hope that helps.,

Input.threadtitle: Implication Truth-Table: Last two rows
Input.posts:
I follow the logic in the lecture concerning the first two rows for both the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation and the $$\phi \not\implies \psi$$ relations. Those two rows are understandable and consistent. But it seems the last two rows are (arbitrarily) defined, but not rationalized. Why not say that if $$\phi$$ is false then $$\phi \not \implies \psi$$ is always true. That is a false antecedent does not imply any consequent. Then the negation of that would make the last two rows of the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation false instead of true? I am sure I must have missed something key...what was it?

I think the very fact that you can't conclude anything is what makes it make sense. You can't say the implication is false, because what can you conclude from a false antecedent? Nothing. So since we're leaving out causation, they're true. And the logic in the lecture (which is much better than my handwaving) is that there is only *one* condition under which phi does not imply psi is true, where phi is true and psi is false. All other cases are false, because if phi is false you can't conclude anything about psi. That means in the opposite condition we must have one false, and the rest true.

This corresponds to the first line in the table. Suppose it's true that you get an A but it's false that I give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is False . This corresponds to the second line in the table. What if it's false that you get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can't be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table. Explained this way, I (finally) got it and what Keith said about separating the causation part from the truth or conditional part of implication made sense! Another help, frankly, was the use of the letters P and Q instead of the symbols. For some reason, having to read or write (using the inclusive 'or', lol) was getting in the way of my understanding the material.

What would happen if the last two rows were false instead of true? That would just make it another, different logical operator. Apparently '->' is more useful in mathematical contexts. Suppose we left the last two rows undefined or false. Then x->y would only be true when x is true. So if we know x->y is true, it follows that x must be true... and hence that y is true too. But we don't want to be able to conclude from 'x implies y' is true that x is true and y is true, because that's not true about 'x implies y'. And it 'breaks' the proof system, or at least would make x->y non-useful because it would just = x&y.
Upvotes:
0
That's only if *both* the last two rows are undefined or false. But if either of them were false, there would be cases where x->y is false but 'x implies y' is true (we can't conclude anything about 'x implies y' from cases where x is false). So neither of the last two rows can be false, and they can't both be undefined or non-true. Suppose row 3 were true and row 4 undefined. Then it would follow that if x->y is true and x is false, y must be true... but that clearly doesn't follow from 'x implies y'. Likewise, if row 3 were undefined and row 4 true, we could conclude from x->y is true and x is false that y is false, which again doesn't follow from 'x implies y'.

Thanks to everyone who contributed to this thread. It was a good discussion. Since I started the thread I thought I would summarize what you all taught me. First, if $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ is a causal implication , (not just a conditional of non-causally-related statements) then if the first two rows of the truth table are accepted then the next two rows can be accepted since $$\phi = FALSE$$ does not invalidate (and is not inconsistent with) the causal link established in the first two rows. The example I liked the best as a demonstration of this was the implication 'If it rains tomorrow, then I will go to the theater.' If tomorrow it is sunny, then I do not do any damage to the implication by going or not going to the theater. Second, In the case of a pure (non-causal) conditional $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, I am happy to accept the truth table as a definition by mathematicians that works for maintaining valid reasoning when applied in the context of a mathematical proof. In this case it is not necessary to worry about whether or not the relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$ makes sense since there is no relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$. Again, thanks to all who participated.

Hey Robin, I go way back in programming too. I learned BASIC and then programmed in PL/1. By far, the most fun language of all was APL (A Programming Language). I programmed in APL until I left my job around 1990. I believe you are looking at the truth value of the implication in the wrong way. Let's look at your second example since it does not have the else (or first ex and remove the else). In your program, if the machine went haywire and the action failed to execute even though the IF was True, then we would say the implication was false. If the IF was false and the action did not occur, then the code was good. Now, suppose: 1. you had a line of code initializing the variable A to 0 and variable B to 0. 2. you had an if/then statement later that says If A>0, then set B to 0. 3. in #2, the IF condition is false, and the B condition is True. And the code was still good. It worked the way it was supposed to work. Hope that helps.,

I follow the logic in the lecture concerning the first two rows for both the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation and the $$\phi \not\implies \psi$$ relations. Those two rows are understandable and consistent. But it seems the last two rows are (arbitrarily) defined, but not rationalized. Why not say that if $$\phi$$ is false then $$\phi \not \implies \psi$$ is always true. That is a false antecedent does not imply any consequent. Then the negation of that would make the last two rows of the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation false instead of true? I am sure I must have missed something key...what was it?

I think the very fact that you can't conclude anything is what makes it make sense. You can't say the implication is false, because what can you conclude from a false antecedent? Nothing. So since we're leaving out causation, they're true. And the logic in the lecture (which is much better than my handwaving) is that there is only *one* condition under which phi does not imply psi is true, where phi is true and psi is false. All other cases are false, because if phi is false you can't conclude anything about psi. That means in the opposite condition we must have one false, and the rest true.

Here's how I understand it. The key is in considering genuine implication' - it has a notion of causality (mathematical implication does not), i.e. one thing, the antecedent, causes another thing, the consequent. We often use it in daily life. 'If I'm thirsty, I will have a glass of water' is an instance of a genuine implication. We can analyze it if the antecedent 'I'm thirsty' is true. If I'm thirsty and going to have some water, the implication is true - its antecedent is true, so is the consequent ('I will have a glass of water'). In this case the genuine implication holds. But if I'm thirsty and not going to drink some water, it doesn't. Now the genuine implication is false. If the antecedent is false, the genuine implication makes no sense (there's nothing to put a causal relation on). To construct a mathematical notion of implication, we need to define it for the cases in which the antecedent is false. Let's treat genuine implication as a logical operation. We already have two cases representing the relation between the antecedent and the consequent depending on their values - if they are both true, implication holds, if only the first one is true, it is not. But if it is not, then the negation, 'non-implication', must be true. According to genuine implication, it is the only sensible way when non-implication can be true. So the rest three cases of non-implication are considered false. And since implication is the negation of non-implication, we get the truth table as in the lecture. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

So it follows from saying that the truth table of the negation of z will be equivalent to z but with every T and F reversed. We know what not(x->y) is for when x is T, which must be the value for (x->y) when X is F. It's like assuming symmetry and completeness. Does this mean negation is distributive across the truth function (the function that assigns T or F to each variable)? But negation isn't distributive across the logical operators: not(x&y) isn't equivalent to (not x) & (not y). But if we also applied 'not' to 'and' to construct 'not-and' (which would have the reverse truth table of 'and', so it would only be true when both x and y are false), then it is distributive! not(x&y) = (not x) (not &) (not y)

I also had been having trouble understanding the rationale for the last two rows, so I Googled 'explanation of truth table for implication' and found this: To understand why this table is the way it is, consider the following example: 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' The statement will be true if I keep my promise and false if I don't. Suppose it's true that you get an A and it's true that I give you a dollar. Since I kept my promise, the implication is True . This corresponds to the first line in the table. Suppose it's true that you get an A but it's false that I give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is False . This corresponds to the second line in the table. What if it's false that you get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can't be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table. Explained this way, I (finally) got it and what Keith said about separating the causation part from the truth or conditional part of implication made sense! Another help, frankly, was the use of the letters P and Q instead of the symbols. For some reason, having to read or write (using the inclusive 'or', lol) was getting in the way of my understanding the material.

What would happen if the last two rows were false instead of true? That would just make it another, different logical operator. Apparently '->' is more useful in mathematical contexts. When modeling the 'truth' part of implication, we wouldn't want to rule out potentially true implications in cases where it can't be decided yet. Also, something similar already follows from saying that 'not all cars are badly made' is equivalent to 'at least one car is not badly made'. As discussed in a prior thread, it follows that if no instances of x exist, then 'all x are y' is true for all y, which is similar to saying x->y is true whenever x is false. Also, as Devlin says in explaining the conditional, we want '~' to always flip true and false... perhaps that's related to symmetry, a useful property. Devlin also says mathematicians don't like to leave things undefined, so it's worth extending the definition. That same reasoning, extending the Riemann Zeta function to cases outside its original domain, is how mathematicians got 'the zeta-regularized sum of the natural numbers = - 1 / 12', which has proven extremely useful in physics.

But if we had made the last two rows of the truth table false, then there would be cases where x->y would be false but 'x implies y' could be true (since x being false and y being true or false tells us nothing about whether x implies y or not). So making the last two rows false is more useful for proving things about genuine implication.

Suppose we left the last two rows undefined or false. Then x->y would only be true when x is true. So if we know x->y is true, it follows that x must be true... and hence that y is true too. But we don't want to be able to conclude from 'x implies y' is true that x is true and y is true, because that's not true about 'x implies y'. And it 'breaks' the proof system, or at least would make x->y non-useful because it would just = x&y.
Upvotes:
0
That's only if *both* the last two rows are undefined or false. But if either of them were false, there would be cases where x->y is false but 'x implies y' is true (we can't conclude anything about 'x implies y' from cases where x is false). So neither of the last two rows can be false, and they can't both be undefined or non-true. Suppose row 3 were true and row 4 undefined. Then it would follow that if x->y is true and x is false, y must be true... but that clearly doesn't follow from 'x implies y'. Likewise, if row 3 were undefined and row 4 true, we could conclude from x->y is true and x is false that y is false, which again doesn't follow from 'x implies y'.

Thanks to everyone who contributed to this thread. It was a good discussion. Since I started the thread I thought I would summarize what you all taught me. First, if $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ is a causal implication , (not just a conditional of non-causally-related statements) then if the first two rows of the truth table are accepted then the next two rows can be accepted since $$\phi = FALSE$$ does not invalidate (and is not inconsistent with) the causal link established in the first two rows. The example I liked the best as a demonstration of this was the implication 'If it rains tomorrow, then I will go to the theater.' If tomorrow it is sunny, then I do not do any damage to the implication by going or not going to the theater. Second, In the case of a pure (non-causal) conditional $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, I am happy to accept the truth table as a definition by mathematicians that works for maintaining valid reasoning when applied in the context of a mathematical proof. In this case it is not necessary to worry about whether or not the relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$ makes sense since there is no relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$. Again, thanks to all who participated.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hey Robin, I go way back in programming too. I learned BASIC and then programmed in PL/1. By far, the most fun language of all was APL (A Programming Language). I programmed in APL until I left my job around 1990. I believe you are looking at the truth value of the implication in the wrong way. Let's look at your second example since it does not have the else (or first ex and remove the else). In your program, if the machine went haywire and the action failed to execute even though the IF was True, then we would say the implication was false. If the IF was false and the action did not occur, then the code was good. Now, suppose: 1. you had a line of code initializing the variable A to 0 and variable B to 0. 2. you had an if/then statement later that says If A>0, then set B to 0. 3. in #2, the IF condition is false, and the B condition is True. And the code was still good. It worked the way it was supposed to work. Hope that helps.,

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
RequesterFeedback: Hey all, if the instructor is replying to people collectively, please only mark the first relevant post as in the instructions
Input.threadtitle: Implication Truth-Table: Last two rows
Input.posts:
I follow the logic in the lecture concerning the first two rows for both the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation and the $$\phi \not\implies \psi$$ relations. Those two rows are understandable and consistent. But it seems the last two rows are (arbitrarily) defined, but not rationalized. Why not say that if $$\phi$$ is false then $$\phi \not \implies \psi$$ is always true. That is a false antecedent does not imply any consequent. Then the negation of that would make the last two rows of the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation false instead of true? I am sure I must have missed something key...what was it?

I think the very fact that you can't conclude anything is what makes it make sense. You can't say the implication is false, because what can you conclude from a false antecedent? Nothing. So since we're leaving out causation, they're true. And the logic in the lecture (which is much better than my handwaving) is that there is only *one* condition under which phi does not imply psi is true, where phi is true and psi is false. All other cases are false, because if phi is false you can't conclude anything about psi. That means in the opposite condition we must have one false, and the rest true.

I think for some people it 'doesn't feel right' to fill in the last rows with Ts because they think: 'I don't know anything about psi if phi is false, so I leave it blank (or put question marks in there)'. The problem would be that a computer can't 'put a question mark in there', it only knows zeros and ones, so it has to make a decision (or alternatively, warn the programmer that there is not enough information to do the calculation correctly and demand more input, which would be much better and safer) So it has to make a 'strategic decision', *until* it gets additional information about what happens if psi is true (or false). I think to fill in the last rows with T makes a lot more sense as soon as we try to combine our implication 'phi implies psi' with a second, 'reverse' implication like 'psi implies phi' or 'not psi implies phi' using conjunction and/or disjunction, where the 'reverse' implication might contradict our original implication, if we put F in one or both of the rows. Here's how I understand it. The key is in considering genuine implication' - it has a notion of causality (mathematical implication does not), i.e. one thing, the antecedent, causes another thing, the consequent. We often use it in daily life. 'If I'm thirsty, I will have a glass of water' is an instance of a genuine implication. We can analyze it if the antecedent 'I'm thirsty' is true. If I'm thirsty and going to have some water, the implication is true - its antecedent is true, so is the consequent ('I will have a glass of water'). In this case the genuine implication holds. But if I'm thirsty and not going to drink some water, it doesn't. Now the genuine implication is false. If the antecedent is false, the genuine implication makes no sense (there's nothing to put a causal relation on). To construct a mathematical notion of implication, we need to define it for the cases in which the antecedent is false. Let's treat genuine implication as a logical operation. We already have two cases representing the relation between the antecedent and the consequent depending on their values - if they are both true, implication holds, if only the first one is true, it is not. But if it is not, then the negation, 'non-implication', must be true. According to genuine implication, it is the only sensible way when non-implication can be true. So the rest three cases of non-implication are considered false. And since implication is the negation of non-implication, we get the truth table as in the lecture. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

So it follows from saying that the truth table of the negation of z will be equivalent to z but with every T and F reversed. We know what not(x->y) is for when x is T, which must be the value for (x->y) when X is F. It's like assuming symmetry and completeness. Does this mean negation is distributive across the truth function (the function that assigns T or F to each variable)? But negation isn't distributive across the logical operators: not(x&y) isn't equivalent to (not x) & (not y). But if we also applied 'not' to 'and' to construct 'not-and' (which would have the reverse truth table of 'and', so it would only be true when both x and y are false), then it is distributive! not(x&y) = (not x) (not &) (not y)

I also had been having trouble understanding the rationale for the last two rows, so I Googled 'explanation of truth table for implication' and found this: To understand why this table is the way it is, consider the following example: 'If you get an A, then I'll give you a dollar.' The statement will be true if I keep my promise and false if I don't. Suppose it's true that you get an A and it's true that I give you a dollar. Since I kept my promise, the implication is True . This corresponds to the first line in the table. Suppose it's true that you get an A but it's false that I give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is False . This corresponds to the second line in the table. What if it's false that you get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can't be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table. Explained this way, I (finally) got it and what Keith said about separating the causation part from the truth or conditional part of implication made sense! Another help, frankly, was the use of the letters P and Q instead of the symbols. For some reason, having to read or write (using the inclusive 'or', lol) was getting in the way of my understanding the material.

I found an example that is similar to the dollar, with a soda pop machine, it also feels convincing: If you don't put any money into the soda-pop machine, and it gives you a bottle of soda anyway, do you have grounds for complaint? Has it violated the principle, 'if you put money in, then a soda comes out'? I wouldn't think you have grounds for complaint. If the machine gives a soda to every passerby, then it is still obeying the principle that if one puts money in, one gets a soda out. Similarly, the only grounds for complaint against p→q is the situation where p is true, but q is false. This is why the only F entry in the truth table occurs in this row. If you imagine putting an F on the row to which you refer, the truth table becomes the same as what you would expect for p⟺q , but we don't expect that 'if p, then q' has the same meaning as 'p if and only if q'. http://math.stackexchange.com/questions/70736/not-understanding-this-row-of-truth-table-for-logical-...

Suppose we left the last two rows undefined or false. Then x->y would only be true when x is true. So if we know x->y is true, it follows that x must be true... and hence that y is true too. But we don't want to be able to conclude from 'x implies y' is true that x is true and y is true, because that's not true about 'x implies y'. And it 'breaks' the proof system, or at least would make x->y non-useful because it would just = x&y.
Upvotes:
0
That's only if *both* the last two rows are undefined or false. But if either of them were false, there would be cases where x->y is false but 'x implies y' is true (we can't conclude anything about 'x implies y' from cases where x is false). So neither of the last two rows can be false, and they can't both be undefined or non-true. Suppose row 3 were true and row 4 undefined. Then it would follow that if x->y is true and x is false, y must be true... but that clearly doesn't follow from 'x implies y'. Likewise, if row 3 were undefined and row 4 true, we could conclude from x->y is true and x is false that y is false, which again doesn't follow from 'x implies y'.

Thanks to everyone who contributed to this thread. It was a good discussion. Since I started the thread I thought I would summarize what you all taught me. First, if $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$ is a causal implication , (not just a conditional of non-causally-related statements) then if the first two rows of the truth table are accepted then the next two rows can be accepted since $$\phi = FALSE$$ does not invalidate (and is not inconsistent with) the causal link established in the first two rows. The example I liked the best as a demonstration of this was the implication 'If it rains tomorrow, then I will go to the theater.' If tomorrow it is sunny, then I do not do any damage to the implication by going or not going to the theater. Second, In the case of a pure (non-causal) conditional $$\phi \Rightarrow \psi$$, I am happy to accept the truth table as a definition by mathematicians that works for maintaining valid reasoning when applied in the context of a mathematical proof. In this case it is not necessary to worry about whether or not the relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$ makes sense since there is no relation between $$\phi$$ and $$\psi$$. Again, thanks to all who participated.

Instructor's Post
Hey Robin, I go way back in programming too. I learned BASIC and then programmed in PL/1. By far, the most fun language of all was APL (A Programming Language). I programmed in APL until I left my job around 1990. I believe you are looking at the truth value of the implication in the wrong way. Let's look at your second example since it does not have the else (or first ex and remove the else). In your program, if the machine went haywire and the action failed to execute even though the IF was True, then we would say the implication was false. If the IF was false and the action did not occur, then the code was good. Now, suppose: 1. you had a line of code initializing the variable A to 0 and variable B to 0. 2. you had an if/then statement later that says If A>0, then set B to 0. 3. in #2, the IF condition is false, and the B condition is True. And the code was still good. It worked the way it was supposed to work. Hope that helps.,

Title: Linking forum posts -mt-005-5-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
RequesterFeedback: Hey all, if the instructor is replying to people collectively, please only mark the first relevant post as in the instructions
Input.threadtitle: Implication Truth-Table: Last two rows
Input.posts:
I follow the logic in the lecture concerning the first two rows for both the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation and the $$\phi \not\implies \psi$$ relations. Those two rows are understandable and consistent. But it seems the last two rows are (arbitrarily) defined, but not rationalized. Why not say that if $$\phi$$ is false then $$\phi \not \implies \psi$$ is always true. That is a false antecedent does not imply any consequent. Then the negation of that would make the last two rows of the $$\phi \implies \psi$$ relation false instead of true? I am sure I must have missed something key...what was it?

I think the very fact that you can't conclude anything is what makes it make sense. You can't say the implication is false, because what can you conclude from a false antecedent? Nothing. So since we're leaving out causation, they're true. And the logic in the lecture (which is much better than my handwaving) is that there is only *one* condition under which phi does not imply psi is true, where phi is true and psi is false. All other cases are false, because if phi is false you can't conclude anything about psi. That means in the opposite condition we must have one false, and the rest true.
